text:
- Join us on a road trip
(upbeat music)

to the home and heart of
BMW innovation in Munich.
Hold onto your seats because
a brand new BMW operating system,
BMW OS9 is hitting the streets this year.

Gracing both BMW and MINI
compact class vehicles,

the company's newest
technology lets you control
and customize your driving experience.
Get ready because "All Things Automotive"
is taking you for more than a ride.
It's a digital driving symphony
and you're in the conductor's seat.
- Hello, Philipp, Christian.

So, Philip, a few months
ago I came here in Munich

with the idea to develop
infotainment system in the cloud

and I was stunned because
you just say, yeah,

you flipped your computer
and you just show me,

on a browser, the next
generation infotainment system
based on BMW OS9.
I was absolutely stunned.

Christian warned me saying,
"Hey, you'll be impressed."
And I was really impressed about it.

So what was the motivation
that brought you there?

- Our desire was the
project to really innovate
and really go beyond hardware development.

And because with hardware,
you always have the problem,
you cannot really scale it.
It's always super costed and expensive

and it's always bound
to a certain location.
And this is where we said, also,
we would like to make the technology,

especially BMW OS9,
easily accessible people
and that's where we said we use the cloud
and in the end, we want
that they could run in a web browser

because this is something every
BMW employee has installed

so they could use it and
really connecting people
in the product development cycle.

- Philipp, can you tell
us a little bit more
about the BMW OS9?
- Of course, Stefano.
The new BMW Operating System 9

will serve on BMW and MINI
compact class vehicles
from this year on.

- Wow.
- And of course,
the MINI operating system has a UI design
perfectly fitted for the print.
But the cool thing is,
we are leveraging the same tech stack
so it means both are based
on the Android Open Source Project,

which really allows us also
to have third parties' apps,

helps the customer's access
to third party app stores
or services where we, in the end,

but always take care about
our digital sovereignty
because only BMW has access to the data.

- So, Philipp, let's dive
into this demo, right?
I see it open here in a nice browser.
Can you guide us through?

- So our normal web
browser, every BMW employee

has on his laptop and
the cool thing is really,

now we are running the same
software from the cloud

directly streamed to a browser
but normally runs in a car.
That's why I would like to say,
every time you get a new BMW vehicle
and I know you're a passionate BMW driver.
Let's log in, then your personal profile
directly appears in a BMW.

- So we'll finally have a
virtual BMW, My BMW app.
- Yeah, you will-

- Amazing.
- Directly find it afterwards.
- [Stefano] Yeah, awesome.

- So now I would say,
let's hit the BMW ID.
And now scan the QR code.
- Yeah, I can use my phone to scan it.
There we go.

Yeah, there we go.
- And now you see.
- Wow! Amazing.
- It's like magic.

- Yeah.
- And now it also
will directly appear in your My BMW app
because, of course, you're fully connected
with the connected drive backend system

and this is now looking
like a real vehicle.
- Can we see something else in this demo?
- Let's log in.

- [Christian] Okay, let's
log into my Spotify account.
- [Philipp] So it's a kind of an
hybrid experience right now.
It's My BMW with Christian music.

- Yeah.
- Yeah.
(Stefano laughing)
- And now what we could do is,
we could listen to songs,
which we sing in our car.
- [Stefano] Yeah, yeah, absolutely.
- It's a good way to have a lot of fun.

- Thank you so much for
guiding us through this demo

and I think the best thing
that we can do right now

is to have a look at the
architecture that supports it.
- Great idea.
So let's start on the right side
with a BMW software factory,

which is responsible for
building the BMW OS9 images.

And everything starts with the
Amazon EventBridge scheduler,

which is triggering a
Lambda function once a day.

And this Lambda function
is looking up information
in an Amazon Elastic Container Registry

about which docker images
are already available

in the registry but also
looking up information
from Artifactory about which
BMW OS9 images are available.
- [Stefano] Of course.

- [Christian] And then
based on this information,

is triggering an
parameterized CodePipeline,
which executes a couple AWS code builds.
And as a result of each code build,

of course, we will store
a new docker images

for the BMW Cloud OS9 in Amazon
Elastic Container Registry

but also storing some
relevant metadata information
in DynamoDB, which is done,
required and used in the second use case.
Philipp will guide you through.
- After we did all the plumbing,

we have now our Cloud
OS9 images ready to go.
We created the BMW Cloud OS9 Portal
because as we said in the beginning,
we would like the technology
is super accessible for our users.
And in the BMW Cloud OS9 Portal,

you can see all current
running BMW Cloud OS9 instances

but you can also create
or delete these instances.
And everything what we do here, from,
we are serving out of an S3 bucket,

as a static website.
- A static website, yeah.
- [Philipp] And when our user would like
to create a new BMW Cloud OS9 instance,
we use the Amazon API Gateway
and the Lambda function
to get the relevant meta information

out of Amazon DynamoDB
like the software version.
And then,
if the user said,
I would really would like to create one,
you can select, do you want the BMW brand?
Do you want the MINI branch?

Also, which VIN do you
want to assign to it?
And of course, which software version.
- And as we have seen in the demo,
BMW also integrated this solution
into a third party services like Mapbox
for the navigation app.
But of course, BMW also integrated this
in the BMW ConnectedDrive backend,

which is powered by almost
1,000 microservices.
- [Stefano] Wow.
- And BMW just finished the migration
to AWS in May, 2023.
- So 10,000 builds,
1,000 microservices.

We are really talking
about scale here, right?
- Everything, though, what we do, we do it
in scale and I think we do it

quite good.
- Yeah, yeah.
It's amazing.
- [Philipp] And then in the end,
if everything is launched in the cloud,

you need to access it from
the BMW corporate network.
That's why we taking care in the end
to proficiency in Network Load Balancer

with the right ports for
the Cloud OS9 instances,

then the end, a developer
can directly connect
from Android Studio or you can connect
via the web browser to the instance,
or you can also use it via the terminal.
- [Stefano] Terminal.

- And this is really how we
build everything together.
And everything is super automatic
but in the end the cool thing is,
it just takes us two minutes
from hitting the start button
to really be ready to go.

- Can you give us a
little bit more details
about the EC2 instances,
what the Lambdas are doing and so on?
- Yeah, of course.
What you see here is we are using
Spot Metal Instances and we need metal
because we need full virtualization

and the full performance also
for the user experiences.
And on top of that, of course,
we have everything dockerized
and then we launch our docker containers.

Then there is a little bit
more behind the scenes.
Like if you have the docker container,

we need to make sure that the
username and the password,
what the user before requested,
is also assigned to the docker container.
After that, we need to create the right
Cloud OS9 instance, which means
to assign the right VIN,
start it with the right brands,
is an app CPU and enough memory.

Then we need to take care about
all the proper forwarding,

what you saw on the Load
Balancer, as you know.
So we need to create all ports
at the docker container level.
And of course, we need to connect securely
to the BMW connected drive backend
and to the support third party services.
Then we are finished.
And the really cool thing is,
when our user selects,
hey, please create the instance,
after two minutes, we are ready to go.

And you can already experience
this in the web browser.

And I think it's a lot of
stuff to do behind the scenes.
A lot of scripts involved
to really do it in the right order
but it really allowed us

to move fast and to
have a reliable system.

- So, Philipp, what BMW
built is just amazing

but I see a lot of things
that can come down the road,
following this path that you started.
So what are you building next?
- The next thing is really
to have more ECUs running in the cloud.
And we have other teams at BMW working on

virtualization of the
ECU for climatization.

- Yes.
- Or

the ECU who makes a vehicle
to cloud connectivity.

And we really think
(bright music)
to bring all of that

together.
- Together

- [Narrator] As we bring
this road trip to a close,

the big loop of connected
mobility innovation

lies ahead of us, painted
in the bold strokes
of BMW's visionary spirit.

Imagine a realm where
customers, developers,

dealerships, and product
managers converge upon
the same orchestration of technology.
With every line of code,
every connection forged
and every boundary shattered,
BMW has not just built vehicles,
but an ecosystem of transformation.
The road trip is just beginning,
as BMW's holistic architecture

continues to rewrite the
future of connectivity.
